ass="word-wrap-span">THE ass="word-wrap-span">MUSICAL ass="word-wrap-span">adaptation of “Les Misérables”, originally a novel in which ass="word-wrap-span">THE author asks his readers to sympathise with ass="word-wrap-span">THE failed revolutionaries of early-19th-century ass="word-wrap-span">ass="word-wrap-span">France, is probably ass="word-wrap-span">THE most successful ass="word-wrap-span">THEatrical production of ass="word-wrap-span">THE neo-liberal age. ass="word-wrap-span">THE ass="word-wrap-span">English-language version, which ran in London from 1985 until earlier this year, is ass="word-wrap-span">THE longest-ever running ass="word-wrap-span">MUSICAL in ass="word-wrap-span">THE ass="word-wrap-span">West ass="word-wrap-span">End, and ass="word-wrap-span">THE second longest-running ass="word-wrap-span">MUSICAL in ass="word-wrap-span">THE world. Its best-known song—“Do you hear ass="word-wrap-span">THE people sing?”—is increasingly sung at protest marches around ass="word-wrap-span">THE world. It has been sung (in ass="word-wrap-span">Cantonese) several times inside ass="word-wrap-span">THE terminal of ass="word-wrap-span">Hong ass="word-wrap-span">Kong ass="word-wrap-span">International ass="word-wrap-span">Airport during protests over ass="word-wrap-span">THE past week.

ass="word-wrap-span">There are some similarities with ass="word-wrap-span">The 19th-century street protest depicted in “Les Misérables”. ass="word-wrap-span">Both groups are inspired by liberal values, raass="word-wrap-span">Ther than ass="word-wrap-span">The socialism or communism more commonly associated with ass="word-wrap-span">The revolutions of ass="word-wrap-span">The 20th century. ass="word-wrap-span">And just like ass="word-wrap-span">The narrow medieval streets of Paris in “Les Misérables”, ass="word-wrap-span">The airport’s terminals are also a very good place to hold a protest.

It was easy to build barricades across narrow streets made—as ass="word-wrap-span">The revolutionaries of “Les Misérables” do—with household furniture and goods, turning neighbourhoods into mini-fortresses. Paris’s revolution of 1830 saw over 4,000 barricades put up across ass="word-wrap-span">The city; in that of 1848 ass="word-wrap-span">There were at least 6,000. ass="word-wrap-span">They proved such a menace that ass="word-wrap-span">Emperor ass="word-wrap-span">Napoleon III had ass="word-wrap-span">The medieval streets swept away in ass="word-wrap-span">Europe’s biggest redevelopment project, led by ass="word-wrap-span">Baron Haussmann. ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">Emperor was keen not to be overthrown like so many of his predecessors by barricade-mounted revolutionaries. (ass="word-wrap-span">Instead ass="word-wrap-span">The wide boulevards that replaced ass="word-wrap-span">The city’s narrow ass="word-wrap-span">alleyways made Paris indefensible from ass="word-wrap-span">Prussian cavalry and ass="word-wrap-span">German tanks during invasions in 1870 and 1940).

ass="word-wrap-span">Hong ass="word-wrap-span">Kong’s main airport terminal, designed by Norman ass="word-wrap-span">Foster, the world’s leading post-modern architect, has its own attractive qualities for protesters. As the city’s only airport, it could quickly cripple transport links to the rest of the world. ass="word-wrap-span">And as such, a protest would gain international media coverage quickly. It also has very good public transport connections to ferry protesters quickly in ass="word-wrap-span">And out.

ass="word-wrap-span">When riot police tried to clear ass="word-wrap-span">The terminal on ass="word-wrap-span">August 13th ass="word-wrap-span">They were swiftly forced out. ass="word-wrap-span">That was, in part, because ass="word-wrap-span">The protesters used metal airport baggage trollies to defend ass="word-wrap-span">Their position inside ass="word-wrap-span">The airport. ass="word-wrap-span">And here ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">architecture lent itself to ass="word-wrap-span">The protestors’ advantage. ass="word-wrap-span">The most famous bits of Mr ass="word-wrap-span">Foster’s design are its glass walls, open departure halls ass="word-wrap-span">And narrow glass walkways over deep atriums. ass="word-wrap-span">The walkways could easily be blocked by improvised barricades. ass="word-wrap-span">The glass walls ass="word-wrap-span">And open spaces meant ass="word-wrap-span">The police were less able to use violence without being caught on camera.

ass="word-wrap-span">But it is not ass="word-wrap-span">The only building designed by Mr ass="word-wrap-span">Foster to have housed protests. ass="word-wrap-span">Hong ass="word-wrap-span">Kong ass="word-wrap-span">Airport’s design—wide open departure halls flanked by glass walls—was inspired by that of Stansted ass="word-wrap-span">Airport, built in ass="word-wrap-span">Britain earlier in ass="word-wrap-span">The 1990s. He also used ass="word-wrap-span">The same philosophy in a building for Cambridge ass="word-wrap-span">University’s ass="word-wrap-span">Faculty of ass="word-wrap-span">Law, which looks so similar to an ass="word-wrap-span">Airport terminal that ass="word-wrap-span">Students joke he got ass="word-wrap-span">The plans mixed up with those for Stansted. In 2009, ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">Faculty of ass="word-wrap-span">Law building was ass="word-wrap-span">The target of a sit-in protest about humanitarian relief for ass="word-wrap-span">Palestine after ass="word-wrap-span">The Gaza ass="word-wrap-span">War of 2008-9; so were buildings in several oass="word-wrap-span">Ther universities. ass="word-wrap-span">Students chose ass="word-wrap-span">The building for very similar reasons to protesters in ass="word-wrap-span">Hong ass="word-wrap-span">Kong. ass="word-wrap-span">The walls are transparent, offering good views of ass="word-wrap-span">The sit-ins to any would-be ass="word-wrap-span">Student journalists. ass="word-wrap-span">And ass="word-wrap-span">The building has only one usable entrance ass="word-wrap-span">And staircase; access to each floor is along relatively narrow walkways. So a sit-in protest blockading ass="word-wrap-span">The lobby ass="word-wrap-span">And walkways could shut it down very quickly.

ass="word-wrap-span">The oass="word-wrap-span">Ther buildings on that campus were built in ass="word-wrap-span">The 1960s, at ass="word-wrap-span">The height of violent student protest in Cambridge, which culminated in ass="word-wrap-span">The pillaging of ass="word-wrap-span">The city’s poshest hotel in 1970. ass="word-wrap-span">And so ass="word-wrap-span">The buildings of that era were designed with multiple entrances ass="word-wrap-span">And staircases to ensure that lectures could continue even if several entrances were blockaded. ass="word-wrap-span">But by ass="word-wrap-span">The 1990s—when ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">Law ass="word-wrap-span">Faculty building, Stansted ass="word-wrap-span">And ass="word-wrap-span">Hong ass="word-wrap-span">Kong’s airport were built—protests, student-led or not, had become much less frequent in ass="word-wrap-span">Western countries. ass="word-wrap-span">Indeed, as ass="word-wrap-span">Francis Fukuyama famously wrote in 1992, ass="word-wrap-span">The triumph of liberalism meant “ass="word-wrap-span">The end of history”, ass="word-wrap-span">And of big, conflictual political debates, had arrived. ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">architectural lessons of ass="word-wrap-span">The student protests of ass="word-wrap-span">The 1960s were thus forgotten.

It is perhaps unsurprising that ass="word-wrap-span">The postmodern terminals of ass="word-wrap-span">Hong ass="word-wrap-span">Kong’s airport and ass="word-wrap-span">The music of “Les Misérables” have become ass="word-wrap-span">The symbols of ass="word-wrap-span">The revived battle between liberal democracy and ass="word-wrap-span">The ever more authoritarian regimes of countries such as ass="word-wrap-span">China. ass="word-wrap-span">Yet ass="word-wrap-span">The fate of ass="word-wrap-span">The revolutionaries in ass="word-wrap-span">The musical, and in Mr ass="word-wrap-span">Foster’s ass="word-wrap-span">Law ass="word-wrap-span">Faculty, show how hard it may be for ass="word-wrap-span">Hong ass="word-wrap-span">Kong’s protest movement to succeed. ass="word-wrap-span">Most of those on ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">Parisian barricades were shot dead by ass="word-wrap-span">The time ass="word-wrap-span">The curtains fall in “Les Misérables”. ass="word-wrap-span">The protest in Cambridge’s ass="word-wrap-span">Law ass="word-wrap-span">Faculty was ass="word-wrap-span">The longest-lasting protest about Gaza in any British university in 2009, ass="word-wrap-span">But it was also ass="word-wrap-span">The only one that ended with ass="word-wrap-span">The university authorities refusing to cave into any of ass="word-wrap-span">The protesters’ demands to help ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">Palestinian cause. ass="word-wrap-span">Hong ass="word-wrap-span">Kong airport’s ass="word-wrap-span">architecture may suit a protest or a revolution well. ass="word-wrap-span">But wheass="word-wrap-span">Ther that gives it any greater chance of success is anoass="word-wrap-span">Ther question.

eg2: If you have this quality in your relationship already, perhaps you can Foster it so you can hold onto it.
如果在这段关系中你已经具备了这种能力，也许你可以培养它，因此掌握它。
We need to Foster these relationships again and invest in our young people's wellbeing so that they have somewhere to go or to turn to when they are feeling lonely.
我们需要重新培养这些关系并对我们的年轻人的福利进行投资，这样当他们感觉孤独的时候他们就有地方可去或有人可以寻求帮助。
We all should Foster those invaluable relationships that push us to the next level.
我们都应该促进这些宝贵的推动我们走下去的人际关系。
